item.description: 1 Enzyme 2 ATP Synthase 3 Fluorescence spectroscopy 4 High-resolution Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy. 5 Electrospray mass spectrometry. 6 Analytical ultracentrifugation: equilibrium sedimentation. 1 Enzyme 2 ATP Synthase 3 Fluorescence spectroscopy 4 High-resolution Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy. 5 Electrospray mass spectrometry. 6 Analytical ultracentrifugation: equilibrium sedimentation. \[ M = \dfrac{2RT}{(1-v\rho)\omega^2}\dfrac{d(\ln(c))}{dr^2} \] \[ M = \dfrac{2\times 8.314\times298.15}{(1-0.74)\times27000^2}\dfrac{d(\ln(c))}{dr^2} = 2.6156\times10^{-5}\dfrac{d(\ln(c))}{dr^2} \] r = c(6.918, 6.923, 6.924, 6.929, 6.932, 6.935, 6.942, 6.943, 6.

item.title: Radioactivity Worksheet
item.description: Guinea pig A guinea pig was given a single injection of 24NaCl (0.5ml of 0.5\(\mu\)Ci/ml). Subsequently, 0.2 ml samples of blood were taken at intervals and counted for radioactivity. The following results were obtained. The efficiency of counting 24Na is 30%. (a) Given that the radioactive half-life of 24Na is 15h, calculate the biological half life of Na+ in the guinea pig body. Why are these values different? Radioactive decay is a first-order process, so the rate of decay is proportional to the amount of the decaying substance.
